summary: a previously healthy 60-year-old man presented to the emergency room because of a 4-day history of fever, shortness of breath, cough with yellowish sputum, and left side chest pain. he was admitted to the ICU as a case of pneumonia and was started on broad-spectrum antibiotics. myopericarditis, ischemic cardiomyopathy presented with acute coronary syndrome, and stress-induced cardiomyopathy. a differential diagnosis of the severe LV dysfunction included myopericarditis, ischemic cardiomyopathy presented with acute coronary syndrome. laboratory tests were negative for viruses known to cause myocarditis. influenza, parainfluenza, adenovirus, coxsackievirus B, parvovirus B19, echovirus, Epstein–Barr virus, hepatitis C virus, and human immunodeficiency virus were negative for any growth. the elevated level of troponin is known to occur in about 35% of myocarditis cases. the signal response from normal myocardium is reduced during LGE imaging. the distribution of LGE in the sub-epicardial region is consistent with myocarditis. echocardiography performed 3 months after the first one. 50% of patients with acute myocarditis developed chronic ventricular systolic dysfunction.
